scenario: A physician documents that a patient has bilateral knee pain. The coder needs to understand the prefix to assign the correct modifier.
explanation: The prefix 'bi-' means two or both. Bilateral means pertaining to both sides. In medical coding, bilateral procedures may require modifier -50 or separate codes for each side. 'Uni-' means one, 'tri-' means three, and 'hemi-' means half.

scenario: A pathology report describes a hyperplastic polyp found during colonoscopy. The coder must understand the terminology to select the correct diagnosis code.
explanation: The prefix 'hyper-' means above normal, excessive, or beyond. Hyperplasia means excessive cell growth. Hypertension means elevated blood pressure. The opposite prefix 'hypo-' means below normal or deficient. 'Peri-' means around, and 'a-' or 'an-' means without.

scenario: A surgeon documents performing a subcutaneous injection. The coder needs to understand the anatomical location for proper code selection.
explanation: The prefix 'sub-' means below, under, or beneath. Subcutaneous means under the skin. Sublingual means under the tongue. Subdural means below the dura mater. 'Supra-' means above, 'peri-' means around, and 'inter-' means between.

scenario: An operative report describes a periarticular fracture of the knee. The coder must understand the prefix to determine the fracture location.
explanation: The prefix 'peri-' means around or surrounding. Periarticular means around a joint. Pericardium means the membrane around the heart. Periosteum is the membrane around bone. 'Intra-' means within, 'trans-' means through or across, and 'supra-' means above.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient is postoperative day two following a cholecystectomy.
explanation: The prefix 'post-' means after. Postoperative means after surgery. Postpartum means after childbirth. Postmortem means after death. 'Pre-' means before, 'intra-' can mean during (as in intraoperative), and 'a-' means without.

scenario: A radiology report describes a transhepatic cholangiogram. The coder needs to understand the approach described.
explanation: The prefix 'trans-' means through or across. Transhepatic means through the liver. Transurethral means through the urethra. Transcutaneous means through the skin. 'Sub-' means below, 'peri-' means around, and 'intra-' means within.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with tachycardia. The physician documents a heart rate of 120 beats per minute.
explanation: The prefix 'tachy-' means fast or rapid. Tachycardia means rapid heart rate (typically >100 bpm). Tachypnea means rapid breathing. The opposite prefix 'brady-' means slow (bradycardia = slow heart rate). 'Dys-' can mean abnormal or difficult, and 'a-' means absent.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has anemia. The coder needs to understand the prefix to properly code the condition.
explanation: The prefix 'an-' or 'a-' means without or absence of. Anemia means without (sufficient) blood. Apnea means without breathing. Anesthesia means without sensation. 'Hyper-' means excessive, 'eu-' means normal or good, and 'dys-' means painful or difficult.

scenario: A patient undergoes an intravenous pyelogram. The coder needs to understand the route of contrast administration.
explanation: The prefix 'intra-' means within or inside. Intravenous means within a vein. Intramuscular means within a muscle. Intracranial means within the skull. 'Inter-' means between (e.g., intervertebral = between vertebrae). 'Extra-' means outside, and 'supra-' means above.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has dysphagia following a stroke. The coder must identify the correct ICD-10 code.
explanation: The prefix 'dys-' means painful, difficult, or abnormal. Dysphagia means difficulty swallowing. Dyspnea means difficulty breathing. Dysuria means painful urination. Dysfunction means abnormal function. 'Eu-' means normal or good, 'a-' means without, and 'hyper-' means excessive.

scenario: A surgeon performs a cholecystectomy. The coder must understand the suffix to determine what procedure was performed.
explanation: The suffix '-ectomy' means surgical removal or excision. Cholecystectomy means removal of the gallbladder. Appendectomy means removal of the appendix. Tonsillectomy means removal of the tonsils. '-plasty' means surgical repair, '-otomy' means incision into, and '-oscopy' means visual examination.

scenario: A patient undergoes a rhinoplasty. The coder needs to understand the suffix to determine the type of procedure.
explanation: The suffix '-plasty' means surgical repair or reconstruction. Rhinoplasty means surgical repair of the nose. Arthroplasty means joint repair/replacement. Angioplasty means vessel repair. '-ectomy' means removal, '-desis' means binding or fixation, and '-tripsy' means crushing.

scenario: A gastroenterologist performs an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD). The coder must understand the suffix to identify the procedure type.
explanation: The suffix '-scopy' means visual examination. Endoscopy means visual examination of the interior. Arthroscopy means visual examination of a joint. Colonoscopy means visual examination of the colon. '-ectomy' means removal, '-graphy' means recording/image, and '-otomy' means incision.

scenario: A pathology report describes cardiomegaly on a chest X-ray. The coder needs to understand the finding for diagnosis coding.
explanation: The suffix '-megaly' means enlargement. Cardiomegaly means enlargement of the heart. Hepatomegaly means enlargement of the liver. Splenomegaly means enlargement of the spleen. '-algia' means pain, '-itis' means inflammation, and '-malacia' means softening.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with appendicitis. The coder must understand the suffix to assign the correct diagnosis code.
explanation: The suffix '-itis' means inflammation. Appendicitis means inflammation of the appendix. Arthritis means inflammation of a joint. Bronchitis means inflammation of the bronchi. '-osis' means condition of, '-pathy' means disease, and '-oma' means tumor.

scenario: A patient undergoes a tracheotomy for airway management. The coder must distinguish this from a tracheostomy.
explanation: The suffix '-otomy' means cutting into or incision. A tracheotomy is an incision into the trachea. A craniotomy is an incision into the skull. '-ectomy' means surgical removal, '-ostomy' means creating a new permanent opening (stoma), and '-rrhaphy' means suturing.

scenario: A patient undergoes a colostomy after bowel resection. The coder needs to understand the suffix for correct procedure coding.
explanation: The suffix '-ostomy' means creating a new opening (stoma). A colostomy creates a new opening from the colon to the abdominal surface. A tracheostomy creates a permanent opening in the trachea. An ileostomy creates an opening from the ileum. '-otomy' means incision, '-ectomy' means removal, and '-desis' means binding.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with a hepatic adenoma. The pathology report describes a benign tumor of the liver.
explanation: The suffix '-oma' means tumor or mass. Adenoma is a benign glandular tumor. Carcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor. Melanoma is a tumor of melanocytes. Hematoma is a collection of blood (not a true neoplasm but uses the same suffix). '-itis' means inflammation, '-emia' means blood condition, and '-algia' means pain.

scenario: A patient presents with arthralgia of the right hip. The physician documents pain without signs of inflammation.
explanation: The suffix '-algia' means pain. Arthralgia means joint pain. Neuralgia means nerve pain. Myalgia means muscle pain. Cephalgia (cephalalgia) means headache. '-asthenia' means weakness, '-itis' means inflammation, and '-edema' means swelling.

scenario: A patient undergoes an electrocardiogram (ECG/EKG). The coder needs to understand the suffix to classify the procedure.
explanation: The suffix '-gram' means a record or image. An electrocardiogram is the record of the heart's electrical activity. A mammogram is an image of the breast. '-graph' means the instrument used for recording, '-graphy' means the process of recording, and '-scopy' means visual examination.

scenario: A physician documents a patient with nephritis. The coder must identify the organ system involved for proper code assignment.
questionText: The root word 'nephr/o' refers to which organ?
explanation: The root word 'nephr/o' refers to the kidney. Nephritis means inflammation of the kidney. Nephrectomy means removal of a kidney. Nephrology is the study of kidney diseases. 'Hepat/o' refers to the liver, 'pneum/o' or 'pulmon/o' refers to the lung, and 'splen/o' refers to the spleen.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with hepatomegaly on abdominal ultrasound. The coder needs to identify the organ involved.
questionText: The root word 'hepat/o' refers to which organ?
explanation: The root word 'hepat/o' refers to the liver. Hepatomegaly means enlargement of the liver. Hepatitis means inflammation of the liver. Hepatectomy means removal of the liver (or part of it). 'Cardi/o' refers to the heart, 'gastr/o' refers to the stomach, and 'pancreat/o' refers to the pancreas.

scenario: A patient undergoes an osteotomy of the tibia. The coder must understand the root word to classify the procedure.
explanation: The root word 'oste/o' refers to bone. Osteotomy means cutting into bone. Osteoporosis means porous bone condition. Osteomyelitis means inflammation of bone and marrow. 'Arthr/o' refers to joint, 'my/o' refers to muscle, and 'chondr/o' refers to cartilage.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The physician documents chronic acid reflux from the stomach into the esophagus.
explanation: The root word 'gastr/o' refers to the stomach. Gastroesophageal means pertaining to the stomach and esophagus. Gastritis means inflammation of the stomach. Gastrectomy means removal of the stomach. 'Enter/o' refers to the intestine, 'esophag/o' refers to the esophagus, and 'cholecyst/o' refers to the gallbladder.

scenario: A patient undergoes a pneumonectomy for lung cancer. The coder must identify the organ system for proper CPT code selection.
explanation: The root word 'pneum/o' refers to air or lung. Pneumonectomy means removal of a lung. Pneumonia means infection/inflammation of the lung. Pneumothorax means air in the thoracic cavity. 'Cardi/o' refers to the heart, 'angi/o' refers to blood vessel, and 'neur/o' refers to nerve.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with dermatitis. The dermatologist prescribes topical corticosteroids for the skin condition.
questionText: The root word 'derm/o' or 'dermat/o' refers to:
explanation: The root word 'derm/o' or 'dermat/o' refers to the skin. Dermatitis means inflammation of the skin. Dermatology is the study of skin diseases. Dermatome is an instrument for cutting skin. 'Trich/o' refers to hair, 'onych/o' refers to nail, and 'lip/o' or 'adip/o' refers to fat.

scenario: A patient undergoes a cystoscopy for evaluation of hematuria. The urologist examines the interior of the bladder.
explanation: The root word 'cyst/o' refers to the bladder or a sac. Cystoscopy means visual examination of the bladder. Cystitis means inflammation of the bladder. Cholecystectomy means removal of the gallbladder (chole = bile + cyst = sac). 'Nephr/o' or 'ren/o' refers to the kidney, 'ureter/o' refers to the ureter.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with encephalitis. The neurologist orders an MRI of the brain.
explanation: The root word 'encephal/o' refers to the brain. Encephalitis means inflammation of the brain. Encephalopathy means disease of the brain. Electroencephalogram (EEG) is a recording of brain electrical activity. 'Myel/o' refers to spinal cord (or bone marrow), 'neur/o' refers to nerve, and 'crani/o' refers to skull.

scenario: A patient undergoes an angioplasty of the right coronary artery. The interventional cardiologist documents the procedure.
explanation: The root word 'angi/o' refers to blood vessel (both arteries and veins). Angioplasty means surgical repair of a blood vessel. Angiography means imaging of blood vessels. Angioma is a tumor of blood vessels. 'Cardi/o' refers to heart, 'hem/o' or 'hemat/o' refers to blood, and 'arteri/o' refers specifically to arteries.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with myocardial infarction. The cardiologist explains the condition involves death of heart muscle tissue.
explanation: The root word 'my/o' refers to muscle. Myocardial means pertaining to heart muscle. Myalgia means muscle pain. Myositis means inflammation of muscle. Myoma is a muscle tumor. 'Oste/o' refers to bone, 'neur/o' refers to nerve, and 'ten/o' or 'tendin/o' refers to tendon.

scenario: A patient undergoes a hysterectomy for uterine fibroids. The gynecologist documents the surgical approach.
explanation: The root word 'hyster/o' refers to the uterus. Hysterectomy means removal of the uterus. Hysteroscopy means visual examination of the uterus. Another root for uterus is 'metr/o' or 'uter/o'. 'Oophor/o' refers to ovary, 'salping/o' refers to fallopian tube, and 'colp/o' or 'vagin/o' refers to vagina.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with thrombocytopenia. The hematologist explains that the patient has a low platelet count.
explanation: The combining form 'thromb/o' refers to a blood clot. Thrombocytopenia means deficiency of clot-forming cells (platelets). Thrombosis means formation of a blood clot. Thrombolysis means dissolution of a clot. 'Erythr/o' refers to red (red blood cell), 'leuk/o' refers to white (white blood cell).

scenario: A patient undergoes a cholecystectomy. The surgeon documents removing the gallbladder laparoscopically.
explanation: The combining form 'chol/e' refers to bile or gall. Cholecystectomy means removal of the bile sac (gallbladder). Cholelithiasis means gallstones (bile + stone + condition). Cholangiography means imaging of bile ducts. 'Cholecyst/o' specifically refers to the gallbladder. 'Hepat/o' refers to liver, 'pancreat/o' refers to pancreas.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with leukocytosis. The physician documents an elevated white blood cell count.
explanation: The combining form 'leuk/o' means white. Leukocyte means white blood cell. Leukocytosis means increased white blood cells. Leukemia means cancer of white blood cells. 'Erythr/o' means red, 'cyan/o' means blue, and 'xanth/o' means yellow.

scenario: A patient undergoes a mammography for breast cancer screening. The radiologist documents the findings.
explanation: The combining form 'mamm/o' refers to the breast. Mammography means imaging of the breast. Mammoplasty means surgical repair of the breast. Another combining form for breast is 'mast/o' (mastectomy = removal of the breast). 'Thorac/o' or 'pector/o' refers to chest, 'cost/o' refers to rib.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with hematemesis. The gastroenterologist documents vomiting of blood.
questionText: The combining form 'hem/o' or 'hemat/o' refers to:
explanation: The combining form 'hem/o' or 'hemat/o' refers to blood. Hematemesis means vomiting blood. Hematuria means blood in the urine. Hematoma means a collection of blood. Hemorrhage means excessive bleeding. 'Hepat/o' refers to liver, 'cardi/o' refers to heart, and 'phleb/o' or 'ven/o' refers to vein.

scenario: A physician orders a CBC for a patient presenting with fatigue. The coder must understand the abbreviation for proper charge capture.
explanation: CBC stands for Complete Blood Count, a common laboratory test that measures red blood cells, white blood cells, hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelets. It is one of the most frequently ordered lab tests and is coded under CPT 85025 (automated) or 85027 (automated with differential).

scenario: A surgeon documents performing a CABG procedure. The coder must identify the correct CPT codes for the operative report.
explanation: CABG stands for Coronary Artery Bypass Graft, a surgical procedure to improve blood flow to the heart by bypassing blocked coronary arteries. The procedure uses grafts from the internal mammary artery, saphenous vein, or radial artery. CPT codes are in the 33510-33536 range depending on the number of grafts.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient's BMI is 32. The coder needs to assign an appropriate ICD-10 code for obesity.
explanation: BMI stands for Body Mass Index, a measure of body fat based on height and weight. A BMI of 30 or greater indicates obesity. BMI categories: underweight (<18.5), normal (18.5-24.9), overweight (25-29.9), obese (30+). ICD-10 codes for BMI are in the Z68 category.

scenario: A patient presents to the ED with chest pain. The physician orders a STAT ECG. The coder must understand the abbreviations used.
explanation: ECG (or EKG, from the German Elektrokardiogramm) stands for Electrocardiogram, a test that records the electrical activity of the heart. It is coded as CPT 93000 (with interpretation) or 93005 (tracing only). An echocardiogram is an ultrasound of the heart. An EEG is an electroencephalogram (brain waves).

scenario: A physician documents that a patient needs a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast. The coder must select the correct radiology CPT code.
explanation: CT stands for Computed Tomography, an imaging technique that uses X-rays and computer processing to create cross-sectional images of the body. CT scans are coded based on body area and whether contrast is used (without contrast, with contrast, or both). Previously called CAT scan (Computed Axial Tomography).

scenario: A patient is admitted to the ICU following a motor vehicle accident. The coder must understand the level of care for E/M coding.
explanation: ICU stands for Intensive Care Unit, a specialized hospital unit providing critical care to seriously ill patients. Critical care E/M codes (99291-99292) are time-based and used for critically ill patients requiring constant physician attention, regardless of the physical location.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient's HbA1c is 8.5%. The coder must understand this lab value for diabetes management coding.
explanation: HbA1c stands for Hemoglobin A1c (glycated hemoglobin), a blood test that reflects average blood sugar levels over the past 2-3 months. It is the standard test for monitoring diabetes management. A normal HbA1c is below 5.7%, prediabetes is 5.7-6.4%, and diabetes is 6.5% or higher.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with cholecystolithiasis. The surgeon recommends laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
explanation: The combining form 'lith/o' refers to a stone or calculus. Cholelithiasis means gallstones. Nephrolithiasis means kidney stones. Lithotripsy means crushing of stones. Urolithiasis means urinary stones. 'Lip/o' or 'adip/o' refers to fat, 'hydr/o' refers to fluid or water.

scenario: A patient undergoes a salpingo-oophorectomy. The coder must understand the combining forms to identify the structures removed.
explanation: The combining form 'salping/o' refers to a tube, specifically the fallopian tube (uterine tube) or eustachian tube. Salpingectomy means removal of a fallopian tube. Salpingo-oophorectomy means removal of the fallopian tube and ovary. 'Oophor/o' refers to ovary, 'hyster/o' or 'metr/o' refers to uterus.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with cardiomyopathy. The cardiologist explains this is a disease of the heart muscle.
explanation: The combining form 'cardi/o' refers to the heart. Cardiomyopathy means disease of the heart muscle. Cardiology is the study of the heart. Cardiomegaly means enlargement of the heart. Tachycardia means rapid heart rate. 'Hem/o' refers to blood, 'thorac/o' refers to chest, 'pulmon/o' refers to lung.

scenario: A patient undergoes a laparoscopic procedure. The surgeon documents using a camera inserted through a small abdominal incision.
explanation: The combining form 'lapar/o' refers to the abdominal wall or abdomen. Laparoscopy means visual examination of the abdomen. Laparotomy means incision into the abdomen. Laparoscopic surgery uses small incisions in the abdominal wall. 'Thorac/o' refers to chest, 'pelv/o' refers to pelvis, 'dors/o' refers to back.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with polyneuropathy. The neurologist documents damage to multiple peripheral nerves.
explanation: The combining form 'neur/o' refers to nerve. Neuropathy means disease of the nerves. Neuralgia means nerve pain. Neurology is the study of the nervous system. Neuritis means inflammation of a nerve. 'Encephal/o' refers to brain, 'myel/o' refers to spinal cord (or bone marrow), 'my/o' refers to muscle.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient needs an MRI of the lumbar spine. The coder must select the appropriate radiology code.
explanation: MRI stands for Magnetic Resonance Imaging, a diagnostic technique that uses magnetic fields and radio waves to create detailed images of organs and tissues. Unlike CT scans, MRI does not use ionizing radiation. MRI is particularly useful for soft tissue imaging (brain, spinal cord, joints, muscles).

scenario: A patient presents with a DVT of the left lower extremity. The physician orders anticoagulation therapy.
explanation: DVT stands for Deep Vein Thrombosis, a blood clot that forms in a deep vein, most commonly in the legs. DVT is a serious condition because the clot can break loose and travel to the lungs (pulmonary embolism). Risk factors include immobility, surgery, and cancer. ICD-10 codes are in the I82 category.

scenario: A radiology report describes a lesion on the anterior chest wall. The coder must understand the directional term to assign the correct body site.

answers.text: The back side of the body
The front side of the body
The upper part of the body

explanation: Anterior (ventral) refers to the front side of the body. Posterior (dorsal) refers to the back side. These directional terms are essential in medical coding for identifying the correct anatomical location. For example, an anterior approach to the spine is from the front, while a posterior approach is from the back.

scenario: A surgeon documents a lateral approach to the hip. The coder must understand the directional term to select the correct surgical approach code.

answers.text: Away from the midline (toward the side)

explanation: Lateral means away from the midline or toward the side of the body. Medial means toward the midline. For example, the lateral malleolus (fibula) is on the outer side of the ankle, while the medial malleolus (tibia) is on the inner side. These terms are critical for accurate anatomical coding.

scenario: A physician documents a proximal femur fracture. The coder must understand the location relative to the body center.

answers.text: Closer to the point of attachment or origin
Farther from the point of attachment or origin

explanation: Proximal means closer to the point of attachment or the trunk of the body. Distal means farther from the point of attachment. For example, the proximal femur is near the hip, while the distal femur is near the knee. The proximal humerus is near the shoulder, and the distal humerus is near the elbow.

scenario: A dermatologist documents a superficial skin lesion on the arm. The coder must understand the depth descriptor for proper code selection.
explanation: Superficial means on or near the surface of the body. Deep (profound) means away from the surface, further into the body. In coding, the distinction between superficial and deep is critical for wound repair codes (12001-12007 for superficial, 12031-12057 for intermediate) and for determining the extent of procedures.

scenario: An MRI report describes a superior labral tear of the shoulder. The coder needs to understand the directional term.
explanation: Superior (cranial or cephalic) means above or upper, toward the head. Inferior (caudal) means below or lower, toward the feet. A SLAP tear is a Superior Labrum Anterior to Posterior tear of the shoulder. The superior vena cava is above the heart, while the inferior vena cava is below.

scenario: A surgeon documents a dorsal approach to the wrist for ganglion cyst excision.

answers.text: The palm side of the hand
The back side of the body or the top of the hand/foot

explanation: Dorsal refers to the back side of the body, or the top of the hand or foot. In the hand, dorsal is the back (knuckle side) and palmar (volar) is the palm side. In the foot, dorsal is the top and plantar is the sole. For the body, dorsal is synonymous with posterior.

scenario: A patient undergoes an electroencephalogram. The coder must identify the body system for proper code categorization.
questionText: The term 'electroencephalogram' refers to a recording of electrical activity of the:
explanation: An electroencephalogram (EEG) is a recording of the electrical activity of the brain. 'Electro-' means electrical, 'encephal/o' means brain, and '-gram' means record. An electrocardiogram (ECG) records heart activity. An electromyogram (EMG) records muscle activity. EEG is coded as CPT 95816-95822.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with osteoarthritis. The physician documents degenerative changes in the weight-bearing joints.
explanation: Osteoarthritis literally means inflammation of bone and joint: 'oste/o' (bone) + 'arthr/o' (joint) + '-itis' (inflammation). Although osteoarthritis is primarily a degenerative condition rather than inflammatory, the name reflects the involvement of both bone and joint structures. Osteomalacia means softening of bone. Osteonecrosis means death of bone tissue.

scenario: A patient undergoes a thyroidectomy. The pathology report describes papillary thyroid carcinoma.

answers.text: A malignant tumor of epithelial tissue
A malignant tumor of connective tissue

explanation: Carcinoma is a malignant (cancerous) tumor arising from epithelial tissue. It is the most common type of cancer. 'Carcin/o' means cancer, '-oma' means tumor. A sarcoma is a malignant tumor of connective tissue (bone, muscle, cartilage). Benign tumors are named by tissue type with '-oma' suffix (e.g., adenoma, lipoma).

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with hypothyroidism. The endocrinologist explains the thyroid gland is underactive.
explanation: Hypothyroidism means deficient (below normal) thyroid function: 'hypo-' (below/deficient) + 'thyroid' + '-ism' (condition). Hyperthyroidism is excessive thyroid function. Thyroiditis is inflammation of the thyroid. A goiter is enlargement of the thyroid. Understanding these prefixes is essential for accurate diagnosis coding.

scenario: A patient presents with hematuria. The urologist orders a cystoscopy to evaluate the source of bleeding.
explanation: Hematuria means blood in the urine: 'hemat/o' (blood) + '-uria' (urine condition). Hematochezia is blood in the stool. Hemoptysis is blood in the sputum (coughing up blood). Hematemesis is blood in the vomit. The suffix '-uria' always relates to a urine condition.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with pneumothorax after a chest injury. The physician documents air in the pleural space.
explanation: Pneumothorax means air in the pleural space (thoracic cavity): 'pneum/o' (air) + 'thorax' (chest). This causes lung collapse. Hemothorax is blood in the chest cavity. Pleural effusion is fluid in the pleural space. Empyema is pus in the pleural space. Pneumonia is infection/inflammation of the lung tissue.

scenario: A patient undergoes a bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The coder must break down the term to understand the procedure.
questionText: Breaking down 'salpingo-oophorectomy,' this procedure involves removal of the:
explanation: Salpingo-oophorectomy means removal of the fallopian tubes and ovaries: 'salping/o' (fallopian tube) + 'oophor/o' (ovary) + '-ectomy' (removal). Bilateral means both sides. This procedure is often performed along with a hysterectomy (removal of the uterus) but is coded separately.

scenario: A coder encounters the term 'sequela' in an ICD-10 code description. The patient has chronic pain from a previous fracture.
questionText: In medical coding, the term 'sequela' refers to:

answers.text: The initial encounter for a condition
A subsequent encounter for routine care
A late effect or residual condition from a previous injury or illness
An acute exacerbation of a chronic condition

explanation: Sequela refers to a late effect or residual condition that remains after the acute phase of an illness or injury has resolved. In ICD-10-CM, sequela codes use the 7th character 'S'. For example, chronic pain following a healed fracture is a sequela. Initial encounter uses 'A' and subsequent encounter uses 'D'.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has a comorbid condition of diabetes mellitus along with the primary diagnosis of pneumonia.

answers.text: A condition that develops during hospitalization
A pre-existing condition that coexists with the primary diagnosis

explanation: Comorbidity refers to a pre-existing condition that coexists with the primary (principal) diagnosis. Comorbidities can affect treatment, length of stay, and reimbursement. A complication is a condition that develops during treatment. In DRG-based payment systems, comorbidities and complications (CCs) can increase reimbursement.

scenario: A coder reviews an operative report and needs to determine the correct laterality for the procedure code.

answers.text: Which side of the body is affected (right, left, or bilateral)

explanation: Laterality refers to which side of the body is affected: right, left, or bilateral (both sides). ICD-10-CM codes include laterality as part of the code structure. For example, a right knee osteoarthritis has a different code than left knee. Modifier -RT (right) and -LT (left) are used with CPT codes when laterality is not inherent in the code.

scenario: A physician documents performing an incision and drainage of a subcutaneous abscess. The coder must understand the anatomical depth.
explanation: Subcutaneous means below (sub-) the skin (cutaneous): the layer of tissue beneath the dermis, also called the hypodermis. Subcutaneous tissue contains fat, connective tissue, and blood vessels. Intradermal means within the skin. Percutaneous means through the skin. Understanding tissue depth is essential for selecting correct procedure codes.

scenario: A patient undergoes lithotripsy for kidney stones. The coder must understand the suffix to classify the procedure.
explanation: The suffix '-tripsy' means crushing or breaking. Lithotripsy means crushing of stones (usually kidney or gallstones). Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) uses shock waves to break stones into smaller fragments. '-plasty' means surgical repair, '-desis' means binding or fixation, '-lysis' means loosening or destruction.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with cardiomyopathy. The cardiologist explains this is a disease process affecting the heart muscle.
explanation: The suffix '-pathy' means disease or suffering. Cardiomyopathy means disease of the heart muscle. Neuropathy means disease of the nerves. Retinopathy means disease of the retina. Nephropathy means disease of the kidney. '-itis' means inflammation, '-oma' means tumor, '-megaly' means enlargement.

scenario: A patient undergoes arthrodesis of the lumbar spine. The coder must understand the suffix to determine the procedure type.
explanation: The suffix '-desis' means binding or fixation, commonly referring to surgical fusion. Arthrodesis means surgical fusion of a joint. Tenodesis means fixation of a tendon. Spinal fusion (spondylodesis) is the binding together of vertebrae. '-lysis' means loosening, '-otomy' means incision, '-ectomy' means removal.

scenario: A physician documents performing a percutaneous needle biopsy of a liver mass.
explanation: The prefix 'per-' means through. Percutaneous means through the skin. This is an important term in medical coding as many procedures are performed percutaneously (through the skin without open incision), such as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and percutaneous biopsies. 'Peri-' means around, 'sub-' means below.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with polycystic kidney disease. The nephrologist explains the condition involves multiple cysts.
explanation: The prefix 'poly-' means many or much. Polycystic means many cysts. Polyuria means excessive (much) urination. Polyneuropathy means disease of many nerves. Polydipsia means excessive thirst. 'Mono-' or 'uni-' means one, 'oligo-' means few, and 'a-' or 'an-' means none or without.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has a retroperitoneal hematoma following a fall.
explanation: The prefix 'retro-' means behind or backward. Retroperitoneal means behind the peritoneum. Retrograde means moving backward (e.g., retrograde pyelogram). Retrosternal means behind the sternum. 'Ante-' or 'pre-' means in front of or before, 'supra-' means above, 'intra-' means within.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with a malignant neoplasm. The oncologist discusses treatment options including chemotherapy.
explanation: The prefix 'mal-' means bad or harmful. Malignant means harmful or tending to become progressively worse (cancerous). Malformation means bad or abnormal formation. Malnutrition means bad nutrition. The opposite prefix 'ben-' (as in benign) means good or not harmful. 'Neo-' means new, 'mega-' or 'macro-' means large.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient's BUN and creatinine levels are elevated, suggesting kidney dysfunction.
explanation: BUN stands for Blood Urea Nitrogen, a laboratory test that measures the amount of nitrogen in the blood from the waste product urea. Elevated BUN levels can indicate kidney dysfunction, dehydration, or high protein intake. BUN is often ordered with creatinine as part of a renal function panel (BMP or CMP).

scenario: A surgeon performs a laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication. The operative report describes wrapping the fundus of the stomach around the esophagus.
questionText: The term 'fundoplication' involves wrapping the fundus of the stomach around the:
explanation: Fundoplication involves wrapping the fundus (upper portion) of the stomach around the lower esophagus to reinforce the lower esophageal sphincter and prevent gastroesophageal reflux. The Nissen fundoplication is a 360-degree wrap. The Toupet is a partial (270-degree) wrap. Understanding surgical terminology helps coders select the correct CPT code.

scenario: A surgeon documents performing an anastomosis during a bowel resection. The coder must understand this surgical term.
explanation: Anastomosis means a surgical connection between two tubular structures, such as two segments of bowel, blood vessels, or ureters. After a bowel resection, the remaining ends are connected (anastomosed) to restore continuity. Types include end-to-end, end-to-side, and side-to-side anastomoses.

scenario: A surgeon performs debridement of a wound. The operative note describes removing necrotic tissue from a chronic wound.

answers.text: Removal of dead, damaged, or infected tissue

explanation: Debridement is the removal of dead (necrotic), damaged, or infected tissue from a wound to promote healing. CPT codes for debridement vary based on depth (skin, subcutaneous, muscle, bone) and method (sharp, mechanical, autolytic). Proper documentation of depth and wound size is essential for accurate coding.

scenario: A surgeon performs a lysis of adhesions during an abdominal procedure. The coder must understand the term.
explanation: Lysis means destruction, loosening, or breakdown. Lysis of adhesions means breaking down scar tissue (adhesions) that has formed between organs or tissues. Thrombolysis means dissolution of a blood clot. Hemolysis means destruction of red blood cells. '-desis' means binding, '-sclerosis' means hardening.

scenario: A physician documents performing a reduction of a dislocated shoulder. The coder must understand the procedure type.

answers.text: Restoring a bone or joint to its normal position
Decreasing the size of a tumor

explanation: Reduction means restoring a bone or joint to its normal anatomical position. Closed reduction is performed without an incision (manipulation). Open reduction requires a surgical incision. ORIF (Open Reduction Internal Fixation) involves surgically opening the site and using hardware to fix the bone. Understanding this term is critical for orthopedic coding.

scenario: A surgeon performs an excisional biopsy of a breast mass. The coder must distinguish this from an incisional biopsy.

answers.text: Removing a small sample of the lesion
Removing the entire lesion for examination
Using a needle to aspirate cells
Scraping the surface of a lesion

explanation: An excisional biopsy removes the entire lesion or mass for pathological examination. An incisional biopsy removes only a portion of the lesion. A needle biopsy (core or fine needle aspiration) uses a needle to obtain tissue or cells. The type of biopsy affects CPT code selection and may determine whether a separate excision code is needed.

scenario: A pathology report describes a benign neoplasm. The coder must understand the term to assign the correct ICD-10 code.
questionText: The term 'benign' in relation to a tumor means:

answers.text: Non-cancerous and not likely to spread

explanation: Benign means non-cancerous and not likely to spread (metastasize) to other parts of the body. Benign tumors generally grow slowly and do not invade surrounding tissues. Malignant means cancerous and capable of spreading. In ICD-10-CM, benign neoplasms are coded in the D10-D36 range, while malignant neoplasms are in C00-C96.

scenario: A pathology report describes metastatic disease in the liver from a primary colon cancer.

answers.text: Spread of cancer from its original site to another part of the body
Transformation of benign cells to malignant

explanation: Metastasis means the spread of cancer from its primary (original) site to a distant site in the body. Cancer can metastasize through the blood or lymphatic system. In ICD-10-CM, secondary (metastatic) neoplasms are coded separately from the primary site. For example, liver metastasis from colon cancer requires codes for both sites.

scenario: A pathology report describes tissue necrosis in a surgical specimen. The coder must understand the finding.
explanation: Necrosis means cell or tissue death, usually due to injury, disease, or lack of blood supply (ischemia). 'Necr/o' means death. Avascular necrosis means bone death due to lack of blood supply. Necrotic tissue must often be debrided. 'Neo-' means new (neoplasm = new growth), '-plasia' means formation, '-trophy' means growth/nourishment.

scenario: A pathology report describes dysplasia of the cervical epithelium. The gynecologist discusses the findings with the patient.

answers.text: Abnormal development or growth of cells

explanation: Dysplasia means abnormal development or growth of cells: 'dys-' (abnormal) + '-plasia' (formation/growth). Cervical dysplasia refers to abnormal cells on the cervix that may be precancerous. Hyperplasia is excessive cell growth. Hypoplasia is underdevelopment. Neoplasia is new abnormal growth. Dysplasia is an important concept in pathology coding.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
explanation: Acute means severe, of sudden onset, and typically of short duration. Chronic means long-lasting, developing slowly over time. An acute exacerbation is a sudden worsening of a chronic condition. In ICD-10-CM, the distinction between acute and chronic conditions affects code selection (e.g., acute vs. chronic kidney disease).

scenario: A physician prescribes an antibiotic for a patient with a bacterial infection. The coder must understand the drug classification.
explanation: The prefix 'anti-' means against. Antibiotic means against life (specifically against bacteria). Anticoagulant means against clotting. Anti-inflammatory means against inflammation. Antihypertensive means against high blood pressure. 'Pro-' means for or supporting, 'syn-' means with or together, 'pre-' means before.

scenario: A patient receives an analgesic medication for postoperative pain management.
explanation: An analgesic is a medication that relieves pain: 'an-' (without) + '-alges' (pain). Common analgesics include acetaminophen, NSAIDs, and opioids. An antipyretic reduces fever. An anti-inflammatory reduces inflammation. An antibiotic prevents or treats infection. Some medications have multiple properties (e.g., NSAIDs are both analgesic and anti-inflammatory).

scenario: A physician prescribes a diuretic for a patient with congestive heart failure and fluid retention.

answers.text: Increasing urine output to reduce fluid

explanation: A diuretic increases urine output (diuresis) to reduce excess fluid in the body. 'Di-' or 'dia-' means through, 'ur/o' means urine. Diuretics are used to treat conditions like heart failure, hypertension, and edema. Common diuretics include furosemide (Lasix), hydrochlorothiazide, and spironolactone.

scenario: A patient on warfarin therapy has their INR monitored. The physician adjusts the anticoagulant dose.
explanation: INR stands for International Normalized Ratio, a standardized measurement of blood clotting time used to monitor anticoagulant therapy (especially warfarin). A normal INR is approximately 1.0. Therapeutic range for most conditions is 2.0-3.0. Higher INR means blood takes longer to clot (increased bleeding risk).

scenario: A coder encounters the term 'etiology' when reviewing documentation for an ICD-10 code assignment.

answers.text: The cause or origin of a disease

explanation: Etiology refers to the cause or origin of a disease. In ICD-10-CM, many combination codes include both the etiology (cause) and manifestation (resulting condition). For example, diabetic retinopathy codes include both the diabetes (etiology) and the eye condition (manifestation). Understanding etiology is essential for proper code selection.

scenario: A physician documents a patient's chief complaint and history of present illness during an office visit.

answers.text: The primary reason the patient seeks medical care

explanation: The chief complaint (CC) is the primary reason the patient seeks medical care, usually stated in the patient's own words. It is a required element of E/M documentation. Examples: 'chest pain,' 'sore throat,' 'follow-up for diabetes.' The chief complaint drives the medical decision-making and code selection for the encounter.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with cholangitis. The gastroenterologist orders blood cultures and starts IV antibiotics.
explanation: The root word 'cholangi/o' refers to bile duct. Cholangitis means inflammation of the bile ducts. Cholangiography means imaging of the bile ducts. Cholangiocarcinoma is cancer of the bile ducts. 'Cholecyst/o' refers specifically to the gallbladder. 'Chol/e' refers to bile in general.

scenario: A patient undergoes a bronchoscopy for evaluation of a persistent cough. The pulmonologist documents the findings.
explanation: The root word 'bronch/o' refers to the bronchus (airway tube leading to the lungs). Bronchoscopy means visual examination of the bronchi. Bronchitis means inflammation of the bronchi. Bronchiectasis means dilation of the bronchi. 'Pulmon/o' or 'pneum/o' refers to the lung, 'trache/o' refers to the trachea, 'pleur/o' refers to the pleura.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with thrombophlebitis of the left leg. The physician orders anticoagulation therapy.
explanation: The combining form 'phleb/o' refers to a vein. Thrombophlebitis means inflammation of a vein with clot formation. Phlebotomy means incision into a vein (blood draw). Phlebitis means inflammation of a vein. Another combining form for vein is 'ven/o' (intravenous = within a vein). 'Arteri/o' refers to artery.

scenario: A patient undergoes a rhinoplasty for a deviated nasal septum. The coder must understand the combining form.
explanation: The combining form 'rhin/o' refers to the nose. Rhinoplasty means surgical repair of the nose. Rhinitis means inflammation of the nasal mucosa. Rhinorrhea means discharge from the nose (runny nose). 'Stomat/o' or 'or/o' refers to the mouth, 'ot/o' refers to the ear, 'pharyng/o' refers to the throat.

scenario: A radiologist describes a lesion in the ipsilateral lung on a chest CT scan.
explanation: Ipsilateral means on the same side of the body. Contralateral means on the opposite side. Bilateral means on both sides. For example, if a patient has breast cancer on the right and a lung nodule on the right, the lung nodule is ipsilateral to the breast cancer. These terms are important for accurate documentation and coding.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient needs a TURP procedure for benign prostatic hyperplasia.
explanation: TURP stands for Transurethral Resection of the Prostate, a surgical procedure to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by removing prostate tissue through the urethra. 'Trans-' means through, 'urethral' refers to the urethra. CPT code 52601 is used for TURP. It is one of the most common urological procedures.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with splenomegaly on physical examination. The physician orders an abdominal ultrasound.
explanation: Splenomegaly means enlargement of the spleen: 'splen/o' (spleen) + '-megaly' (enlargement). Common causes include infections, liver disease, and blood disorders. Splenitis would mean inflammation of the spleen. Splenectomy means removal of the spleen. Understanding word construction helps coders decode unfamiliar medical terms.

scenario: A coder reviews documentation and encounters the term 'manifestation' in relation to a diabetes code.

answers.text: The underlying cause of a disease
A sign, symptom, or condition resulting from an underlying disease

explanation: A manifestation is a sign, symptom, or condition that results from (is caused by) an underlying disease (etiology). In ICD-10-CM, etiology/manifestation coding requires the underlying disease code to be sequenced first, followed by the manifestation code. For example, diabetic retinopathy: diabetes is the etiology, retinopathy is the manifestation.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The coder must identify the fracture location.
explanation: The prefix 'supra-' means above or beyond. Supracondylar means above the condyles. Suprapubic means above the pubic bone. Suprarenal means above the kidney (adrenal). 'Infra-' means below, 'inter-' means between, and 'intra-' means within.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with endocarditis. The cardiologist explains the infection involves the inner lining of the heart.
explanation: The prefix 'endo-' means within or inner. Endocarditis means inflammation of the inner lining of the heart. Endoscopy means looking within. Endometrium is the inner lining of the uterus. 'Exo-' or 'ecto-' means outside, 'peri-' means around, and 'inter-' means between.

scenario: A surgeon documents performing a hemilaminectomy of the lumbar spine.
explanation: The prefix 'hemi-' means half. Hemilaminectomy means removal of half of the lamina. Hemiplegia means paralysis of half of the body. Hemigastrectomy means removal of half of the stomach. 'Pan-' means all or complete, 'bi-' means two or double.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with neonatal jaundice. The pediatrician monitors bilirubin levels.
explanation: The prefix 'neo-' means new. Neonatal means pertaining to a newborn. Neoplasm means new growth (tumor). Neovascularization means new blood vessel formation. 'Paleo-' means old, 'pseudo-' means false, and 'micro-' means small.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has a contralateral knee injury. The coder must understand which knee is affected.
explanation: The prefix 'contra-' means opposite or against. Contralateral means on the opposite side. Contraindication means a reason against a treatment. Contraception means against conception. 'Ipsi-' means same side (ipsilateral), 'bi-' means both sides (bilateral), 'supra-' means above.

scenario: A patient undergoes a nephrectomy with ureterectomy. The pathology report describes renal cell carcinoma.
questionText: The suffix '-uria' refers to a condition of:
explanation: The suffix '-uria' refers to a condition of urine. Hematuria means blood in the urine. Polyuria means excessive urination. Dysuria means painful urination. Glycosuria means glucose in the urine. Anuria means absence of urine production. '-emia' refers to blood conditions, '-bilia' refers to bile.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with thrombocytopenia. The hematologist orders additional blood tests.
explanation: The suffix '-penia' means deficiency or decrease. Thrombocytopenia means decreased platelets. Leukopenia means decreased white blood cells. Neutropenia means decreased neutrophils. Pancytopenia means decrease in all blood cell types. '-cytosis' means increase in cells, '-lysis' means destruction, '-poiesis' means formation.

scenario: A patient undergoes a tenorrhaphy after a tendon laceration. The coder must understand the procedure type.
explanation: The suffix '-rrhaphy' means suturing or surgical repair. Tenorrhaphy means suturing of a tendon. Herniorrhaphy means surgical repair of a hernia. Neurorrhaphy means suturing of a nerve. '-rrhexis' means rupture, '-rrhea' means flow or discharge, '-pexy' means surgical fixation.

scenario: A patient presents with menorrhagia. The gynecologist recommends evaluation for uterine fibroids.
explanation: The suffix '-rrhagia' means excessive bleeding or hemorrhage. Menorrhagia means excessive menstrual bleeding. Hemorrhage means excessive blood flow. Metrorrhagia means irregular uterine bleeding. '-algia' means pain, '-itis' means inflammation, '-rrhea' means discharge or flow.

scenario: A patient undergoes a nephropexy for a ptotic (dropped) kidney. The coder must understand the suffix.
explanation: The suffix '-pexy' means surgical fixation. Nephropexy means surgical fixation of a kidney. Orchiopexy means surgical fixation of a testicle. Gastropexy means surgical fixation of the stomach. Mastopexy means surgical fixation (lifting) of the breast. '-ectomy' means removal, '-otomy' means incision, '-tripsy' means crushing.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with cholecystitis. The surgeon recommends cholecystectomy.
explanation: The root word 'cholecyst/o' refers to the gallbladder (literally 'bile sac'): 'chol/e' (bile) + 'cyst' (sac/bladder). Cholecystitis means inflammation of the gallbladder. Cholecystectomy means removal of the gallbladder. 'Cholangi/o' refers to bile ducts, 'hepat/o' refers to the liver, 'pancreat/o' refers to the pancreas.

scenario: A patient undergoes a thoracotomy for lung surgery. The coder must identify the body region.
explanation: The root word 'thorac/o' refers to the chest (thorax). Thoracotomy means incision into the chest. Thoracoscopy means visual examination of the chest cavity. Thoracentesis means puncture of the chest wall to drain fluid. 'Abdomin/o' or 'lapar/o' refers to the abdomen, 'cervic/o' refers to the neck (or cervix), 'pelv/o' refers to the pelvis.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with spondylolisthesis. The orthopedic surgeon discusses treatment options.
explanation: The root word 'spondyl/o' refers to a vertebra. Spondylolisthesis means forward slipping of one vertebra over another. Spondylosis means degenerative condition of the vertebrae. Spondylodesis (arthrodesis) means fusion of vertebrae. 'Myel/o' refers to spinal cord (or bone marrow), 'disc/o' refers to intervertebral disc, 'cost/o' refers to rib.

scenario: A patient undergoes a craniotomy for brain tumor removal. The coder must understand the root word.
explanation: The root word 'crani/o' refers to the skull (cranium). Craniotomy means incision into the skull. Cranioplasty means surgical repair of the skull. Craniosynostosis means premature fusion of skull sutures. 'Encephal/o' refers to the brain, 'vertebr/o' or 'spondyl/o' refers to the spine/vertebrae, 'faci/o' refers to the face.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with erythrocytosis. The hematologist orders additional testing.
explanation: The combining form 'erythr/o' means red. Erythrocyte means red blood cell. Erythrocytosis means increased red blood cells. Erythema means redness of the skin. Erythropoietin is the hormone that stimulates red blood cell production. 'Leuk/o' means white, 'cyan/o' means blue, 'xanth/o' means yellow.

scenario: A patient undergoes an arthroplasty of the knee. The coder must understand the combining form.
explanation: The combining form 'arthr/o' refers to a joint. Arthroplasty means surgical repair/replacement of a joint. Arthroscopy means visual examination of a joint. Arthritis means inflammation of a joint. Arthrodesis means fusion of a joint. 'Oste/o' refers to bone, 'my/o' refers to muscle, 'tendin/o' refers to tendon.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with cyanosis. The physician documents bluish discoloration of the lips and fingertips.
explanation: The combining form 'cyan/o' means blue. Cyanosis means bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes due to insufficient oxygen in the blood. Central cyanosis (lips, tongue) indicates systemic hypoxemia. Peripheral cyanosis (fingertips, toes) may indicate poor circulation. 'Erythr/o' means red, 'xanth/o' means yellow, 'leuk/o' means white.

scenario: A patient undergoes a pyloroplasty. The surgeon widens the pyloric sphincter to improve gastric emptying.
explanation: The combining form 'pylor/o' refers to the pylorus, the distal opening of the stomach that leads to the duodenum. Pyloroplasty means surgical repair/widening of the pylorus. Pyloromyotomy means incision of the pyloric muscle (for pyloric stenosis in infants). Pyloric stenosis means narrowing of the pyloric sphincter. 'Esophag/o' refers to the esophagus.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has COPD with acute exacerbation. The coder must assign the correct ICD-10 code.
explanation: COPD stands for Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, a group of progressive lung diseases (primarily emphysema and chronic bronchitis) that cause airflow obstruction and breathing difficulty. COPD is coded in ICD-10-CM under J44 (with acute exacerbation: J44.1). It is one of the leading causes of death worldwide.

scenario: A physician orders a BMP for a patient with suspected kidney disease.
explanation: BMP stands for Basic Metabolic Panel, a blood test that measures glucose, calcium, sodium, potassium, chloride, bicarbonate, BUN, and creatinine. It provides information about blood sugar, kidney function, and electrolyte balance. A CMP (Comprehensive Metabolic Panel) includes the BMP plus liver function tests and albumin.

scenario: A surgeon documents a prone position for a posterior spinal approach. The coder must understand the positioning term.
questionText: The term 'prone' means the patient is lying:
explanation: Prone means lying face down (on the stomach/abdomen). Supine means lying face up (on the back). Lateral decubitus means lying on the side. Trendelenburg is supine with the head lower than the feet. Patient positioning affects surgical approach coding and is documented in operative reports.

scenario: A radiologist describes a lesion in the medial compartment of the knee on MRI.
explanation: Medial means toward the midline of the body. The medial compartment of the knee is on the inner side (closer to the other leg). The medial malleolus is the inner ankle bone (tibia). Lateral means away from the midline. Understanding medial vs. lateral is essential for correct anatomical site coding in both ICD-10-CM and CPT.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with cholelithiasis. The surgeon recommends cholecystectomy.
explanation: Cholelithiasis means the presence of gallstones: 'chol/e' (bile) + 'lith' (stone) + '-iasis' (condition). Cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder. Choledocholithiasis is stones in the common bile duct. Cholangiocarcinoma is cancer of the bile ducts. Breaking down medical terms into their components helps coders understand unfamiliar diagnoses.

scenario: A patient presents with dyspnea on exertion. The pulmonologist orders pulmonary function tests.
explanation: Dyspnea means difficult or labored breathing: 'dys-' (difficult) + '-pnea' (breathing). Apnea means absence of breathing. Tachypnea means rapid breathing. Orthopnea means difficulty breathing when lying flat. Bradypnea means slow breathing. These terms describe different respiratory patterns and are important for accurate diagnosis coding.

scenario: A coder encounters the term 'principal diagnosis' when coding an inpatient stay.
questionText: The 'principal diagnosis' in inpatient coding is defined as:

answers.text: The condition established after study to be chiefly responsible for the admission
The first diagnosis listed by the physician
The diagnosis with the highest reimbursement

explanation: The principal diagnosis is defined by the Uniform Hospital Discharge Data Set (UHDDS) as 'the condition established after study to be chiefly responsible for occasioning the admission of the patient to the hospital for care.' It is not necessarily the most severe condition or the admitting diagnosis. Proper selection of the principal diagnosis is critical for DRG assignment and reimbursement.

scenario: A surgeon performs a resection and reanastomosis of the small bowel. The coder must understand both terms.

answers.text: Surgical removal of a portion of an organ or structure

explanation: Resection means surgical removal of a portion (or all) of an organ or structure. Bowel resection means removing a segment of bowel. Liver resection means removing part of the liver. Resection differs from excision in that it typically refers to removing a larger portion of tissue or an entire segment. After bowel resection, the remaining ends are reconnected (reanastomosis).

scenario: A surgeon performs a laparoscopic adhesiolysis. The operative note describes dividing bands of scar tissue between bowel loops.
explanation: Adhesiolysis means destruction or release of adhesions (scar tissue): 'adhesio' (sticking together) + '-lysis' (destruction/loosening). Adhesions are bands of scar tissue that form between organs, often after surgery. They can cause bowel obstruction and pain. Adhesiolysis may be performed open or laparoscopically.

scenario: A surgeon performs an embolectomy of the femoral artery. The operative note describes removing a blood clot from the vessel.

answers.text: Removal of a blood clot that has traveled from another location
Creation of a new blood vessel

explanation: Embolectomy means surgical removal of an embolus (a blood clot or other material that has traveled through the bloodstream and lodged in a vessel): 'embol/o' (plug/clot) + '-ectomy' (removal). A thrombectomy removes a thrombus (clot formed in place). Thrombolysis is dissolution of a clot using drugs. Angioplasty is repair of a blood vessel.

scenario: A surgeon performs a marsupializaton of a Bartholin gland cyst. The coder must understand this procedure type.

answers.text: Opening a cyst and suturing its edges to create a permanent opening for drainage
Aspiration of cyst fluid with a needle
Injection of medication into a cyst

explanation: Marsupialization is a surgical technique where a cyst is opened and its edges are sutured to the surrounding skin or mucosa to create a permanent opening (pouch) for continuous drainage. The term comes from 'marsupium' (pouch), like a marsupial's pouch. It is commonly used for Bartholin gland cysts, pancreatic pseudocysts, and ranulas.

scenario: A pathology report describes a tumor with well-differentiated cells. The oncologist discusses the grading system.

answers.text: Look very different from normal cells and are highly aggressive
Closely resemble normal cells and tend to be less aggressive
Cannot be identified under a microscope

explanation: Well-differentiated tumor cells closely resemble normal cells of the tissue of origin and tend to be less aggressive (lower grade). Poorly differentiated cells look very abnormal and are more aggressive (higher grade). Undifferentiated (anaplastic) cells bear no resemblance to normal cells and are the most aggressive. Tumor grade affects treatment planning and prognosis coding.

scenario: A pathology report describes hypertrophy of the left ventricle. The cardiologist explains the finding.

answers.text: Increase in the number of cells
Increase in the size of cells

explanation: Hypertrophy means an increase in the size of cells (and therefore the organ): 'hyper-' (excessive) + '-trophy' (growth/nourishment). Left ventricular hypertrophy means the heart muscle cells have enlarged. Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells. Atrophy is a decrease in cell size. Necrosis is cell death. These pathology terms are important for accurate diagnosis coding.

scenario: A pathology report describes atrophy of the thymus gland in an elderly patient.

answers.text: Wasting away or decrease in size of an organ or tissue

explanation: Atrophy means wasting away or decrease in size of an organ or tissue: 'a-' (without) + '-trophy' (nourishment/growth). Muscle atrophy occurs from disuse. Thymic atrophy is normal with aging. Cerebral atrophy occurs in dementia. The opposite is hypertrophy (increase in size). '-megaly' also means enlargement, '-itis' means inflammation.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has an ischemic stroke. The neurologist explains the mechanism.

answers.text: Insufficient blood supply to a tissue

explanation: Ischemia means insufficient blood supply to a tissue, resulting in oxygen deprivation: 'isch-' (to hold back) + '-emia' (blood). An ischemic stroke occurs when blood flow to the brain is blocked. Myocardial ischemia means insufficient blood flow to the heart muscle. Prolonged ischemia leads to infarction (tissue death). Hemorrhage means bleeding into tissue.

scenario: A physician prescribes an antihypertensive medication for a patient with high blood pressure.
questionText: The term 'antihypertensive' means a medication that:
explanation: Antihypertensive means a medication that lowers blood pressure: 'anti-' (against) + 'hyper-' (excessive) + 'tens-' (pressure) + '-ive' (pertaining to). Common classes include ACE inhibitors, ARBs, beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, and diuretics. Hypertension (high blood pressure) is coded as I10 in ICD-10-CM.

scenario: A patient on chemotherapy develops neutropenia. The oncologist prescribes a colony-stimulating factor.
questionText: The term 'immunosuppressant' refers to a medication that:

answers.text: Suppresses or reduces the immune response

explanation: An immunosuppressant is a medication that suppresses or reduces the immune response: 'immuno-' (immune system) + 'suppress' (to hold down) + '-ant' (agent). Immunosuppressants are used after organ transplantation to prevent rejection and to treat autoimmune diseases. Examples include cyclosporine, tacrolimus, and mycophenolate. Immunostimulants enhance the immune response.

scenario: A patient with atrial fibrillation is prescribed an anticoagulant. The physician monitors the patient's INR.
explanation: An anticoagulant prevents blood clot formation: 'anti-' (against) + 'coagul-' (clotting) + '-ant' (agent). Common anticoagulants include warfarin, heparin, and direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs). Thrombolytics dissolve existing clots. Antiplatelet agents (like aspirin) prevent platelet aggregation. Anticoagulants do not dissolve existing clots but prevent new ones from forming.

scenario: A coder encounters the term 'modifier' when coding a bilateral knee procedure.

answers.text: A two-digit code appended to a CPT code to provide additional information

explanation: A CPT modifier is a two-digit code (numeric or alphanumeric) appended to a CPT code to provide additional information about the service performed without changing the code's definition. Common modifiers include -50 (bilateral), -RT/LT (right/left), -59 (distinct procedural service), -25 (significant, separately identifiable E/M), and -26 (professional component).

scenario: A coder reviews documentation and encounters the term 'global surgical package' for a surgical procedure.

answers.text: The procedure plus preoperative and postoperative care within a defined period
All services provided during the hospital stay

explanation: The global surgical package includes the surgical procedure itself plus related preoperative care (day before for major surgery), intraoperative services, and postoperative care within a defined follow-up period (0, 10, or 90 days depending on the procedure). Services included in the global period should not be billed separately. Complications and unrelated services may be billed with appropriate modifiers.

scenario: A coder encounters the term 'unbundling' during a coding audit.

answers.text: Properly separating distinct procedures for billing
Improperly billing separately for procedures that should be reported as a single code

explanation: Unbundling is the improper practice of billing separately for procedures that should be reported as a single comprehensive code. For example, billing individual components of a panel lab test separately instead of using the panel code. Unbundling is considered fraudulent billing. The National Correct Coding Initiative (NCCI) edits identify code pairs that should not be billed together.

scenario: A patient undergoes a colectomy for colon cancer. The coder must identify the organ involved.
explanation: The combining form 'col/o' (or 'colon/o') refers to the colon (large intestine). Colectomy means removal of the colon. Colonoscopy means visual examination of the colon. Colostomy means creating an opening from the colon. Colitis means inflammation of the colon. 'Cervic/o' can refer to the neck, 'colp/o' refers to the vagina, 'chol/e' refers to bile.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with ophthalmosclerosis. The ophthalmologist documents hardening of the eye structures.
explanation: The combining form 'ophthalm/o' refers to the eye. Ophthalmology is the study of eye diseases. Ophthalmoscope is an instrument for examining the eye. Ophthalmoplegia is paralysis of eye muscles. Another combining form for eye is 'ocul/o'. 'Ot/o' refers to the ear, 'rhin/o' refers to the nose, 'stomat/o' refers to the mouth.

scenario: A patient undergoes a mastectomy for breast cancer. The coder must understand the root word.
explanation: The root word 'mast/o' refers to the breast. Mastectomy means removal of the breast. Mastitis means inflammation of the breast. Mastopexy means surgical lifting of the breast. Another root for breast is 'mamm/o' (mammography, mammoplasty). 'Mandibul/o' refers to the jaw, 'my/o' refers to muscle, 'myel/o' refers to bone marrow or spinal cord.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with otitis media. The pediatrician prescribes antibiotics.
explanation: The root word 'ot/o' refers to the ear. Otitis media means inflammation of the middle ear. Otoscopy means visual examination of the ear. Otorrhea means discharge from the ear. Otolaryngology is the study of ear, nose, and throat diseases. 'Ophthalm/o' refers to the eye, 'stomat/o' refers to the mouth, 'rhin/o' refers to the nose.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient needs a PSA test for prostate cancer screening.
explanation: PSA stands for Prostate-Specific Antigen, a protein produced by the prostate gland. Elevated PSA levels can indicate prostate cancer, benign prostatic hyperplasia, or prostatitis. PSA testing is used for screening and monitoring prostate cancer. Normal PSA is generally below 4.0 ng/mL, though this varies with age.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has CHF with reduced ejection fraction.
explanation: CHF stands for Congestive Heart Failure, a condition where the heart cannot pump blood effectively, leading to fluid buildup (congestion) in the lungs, legs, and other tissues. It can be systolic (reduced ejection fraction) or diastolic (preserved ejection fraction). ICD-10-CM codes for heart failure are in the I50 category.

scenario: A surgeon documents a distal femur fracture near the knee joint.

answers.text: Closer to the trunk or point of origin
Farther from the trunk or point of origin

explanation: Distal means farther from the trunk or point of origin/attachment. The distal femur is the end near the knee (far from the hip). The distal radius is near the wrist (far from the elbow). Proximal is the opposite, meaning closer to the trunk. In the GI tract, distal means farther along the digestive pathway (e.g., distal colon is closer to the rectum).

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with septicemia. The physician documents a systemic infection.
questionText: The suffix '-emia' refers to a condition of:
explanation: The suffix '-emia' refers to a condition of the blood. Septicemia means infection in the blood. Anemia means deficiency of blood (red blood cells). Hyperglycemia means excessive sugar in the blood. Leukemia means cancer of the white blood cells. '-uria' refers to urine conditions, '-osis' refers to abnormal conditions.

scenario: A patient presents with oliguria after surgery. The physician documents decreased urine output.
explanation: Oliguria means decreased urine production: 'olig/o' (few/scanty) + '-uria' (urine condition). Normal urine output is approximately 0.5-1 mL/kg/hour. Oliguria is typically defined as less than 400 mL per day. Anuria means absence of urine production. Polyuria means excessive urine production. Hematuria means blood in the urine.

scenario: A patient undergoes a paracentesis for ascites. The coder must understand the suffix.
explanation: The suffix '-centesis' means surgical puncture to withdraw fluid. Paracentesis means puncture of the abdominal cavity to drain fluid. Thoracentesis means puncture of the chest to drain fluid. Arthrocentesis means puncture of a joint to drain fluid. Amniocentesis means puncture of the amniotic sac. '-ectomy' means removal, '-scopy' means examination.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with osteomalacia. The physician explains the condition involves softening of the bones.
explanation: The suffix '-malacia' means softening. Osteomalacia means softening of the bones (due to vitamin D deficiency in adults). Chondromalacia means softening of cartilage (e.g., chondromalacia patella). Encephalomalacia means softening of brain tissue. '-sclerosis' means hardening, '-megaly' means enlargement, '-itis' means inflammation.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has paraplegia following a spinal cord injury.
explanation: The prefix 'para-' means beside, near, or abnormal. Paraplegia means paralysis of the lower body (both legs). Parathyroid means beside the thyroid. Paramedic means beside (assisting) a physician. Paranormal means beyond normal. 'Quadri-' means four (quadriplegia = paralysis of all four limbs), 'supra-' means above, 'endo-' means within.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with pseudogout. The rheumatologist explains the condition mimics gout but has a different cause.
explanation: The prefix 'pseudo-' means false or resembling. Pseudogout resembles gout but is caused by calcium pyrophosphate crystals rather than uric acid. Pseudocyst is a false cyst (no true epithelial lining). Pseudomembrane is a false membrane. Pseudoaneurysm is a false aneurysm. Understanding this prefix helps coders distinguish between similar-sounding conditions.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has an extracapsular hip fracture.
explanation: The prefix 'extra-' means outside or beyond. Extracapsular means outside the joint capsule. Extracorporeal means outside the body (e.g., ECMO). Extradural means outside the dura mater. Extraperitoneal means outside the peritoneum. 'Intra-' means within, 'inter-' means between, 'infra-' means below.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with atherosclerosis of the coronary arteries. The cardiologist discusses treatment options.
explanation: The suffix '-sclerosis' means hardening. Atherosclerosis means hardening of the arteries due to plaque buildup. Arteriosclerosis means hardening of arteries in general. Multiple sclerosis involves hardening (scarring) of nerve tissue. Otosclerosis means abnormal hardening of bone in the ear. '-malacia' means softening, '-stenosis' means narrowing, '-ectasia' means widening/dilation.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with bronchiectasis. The pulmonologist orders a CT scan of the chest.
explanation: The suffix '-ectasis' or '-ectasia' means dilation or expansion. Bronchiectasis means dilation of the bronchi. Atelectasis means incomplete expansion of the lung. Telangiectasia means dilation of small blood vessels. '-stenosis' means narrowing, '-itis' means inflammation. Understanding these suffixes helps distinguish between conditions that narrow vs. dilate structures.

scenario: A patient undergoes a spinal stenosis evaluation. The surgeon documents narrowing of the spinal canal.
explanation: The suffix '-stenosis' means narrowing or constriction. Spinal stenosis means narrowing of the spinal canal. Aortic stenosis means narrowing of the aortic valve. Pyloric stenosis means narrowing of the pylorus. Carotid stenosis means narrowing of the carotid artery. '-ectasis' means widening, '-sclerosis' means hardening, '-malacia' means softening.

scenario: A patient undergoes a phlebotomy for polycythemia vera. The coder must understand the root word.
explanation: The root word 'phleb/o' refers to a vein. Phlebotomy means incision into a vein (blood draw). Phlebitis means inflammation of a vein. Thrombophlebitis means inflammation of a vein with clot formation. Another root for vein is 'ven/o' (intravenous = within a vein). 'Arteri/o' refers to artery, 'cardi/o' refers to heart.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with tendinitis of the rotator cuff. The orthopedic surgeon recommends physical therapy.
explanation: The root word 'tendin/o' or 'ten/o' refers to a tendon. Tendinitis (or tendonitis) means inflammation of a tendon. Tenorrhaphy means suturing of a tendon. Tenosynovitis means inflammation of a tendon sheath. Tendons connect muscles to bones. Ligaments connect bones to bones. 'My/o' refers to muscle, 'ligament/o' refers to ligament, 'chondr/o' refers to cartilage.

scenario: A patient undergoes an oophorectomy for an ovarian cyst. The coder must understand the combining form.
explanation: The combining form 'oophor/o' refers to the ovary. Oophorectomy means removal of an ovary. Oophoritis means inflammation of an ovary. Another combining form for ovary is 'ovari/o'. 'Hyster/o' or 'metr/o' refers to the uterus, 'salping/o' refers to the fallopian tube, 'cervic/o' refers to the cervix.

scenario: A patient undergoes a cystolithotomy. The urologist removes a bladder stone through a surgical incision.
questionText: The combining form 'cyst/o' combined with 'lith/o' and '-otomy' means:

answers.text: Incision into the bladder to remove a stone

explanation: Cystolithotomy means incision into the bladder to remove a stone: 'cyst/o' (bladder) + 'lith/o' (stone) + '-otomy' (incision). This demonstrates how combining multiple word parts creates specific medical terms. Cystoscopy is visual examination of the bladder. Cystectomy is removal of the bladder. Lithotripsy is crushing of stones.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient has a PE confirmed by CT angiography.
questionText: The abbreviation 'PE' in this context stands for:
explanation: In this context, PE stands for Pulmonary Embolism, a blood clot that travels to the lungs and blocks a pulmonary artery. PE is a life-threatening condition often caused by deep vein thrombosis (DVT). CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is the standard diagnostic test. PE can also stand for Physical Examination in other contexts - context determines the meaning.

scenario: A physician documents that a patient's LDL cholesterol is elevated at 180 mg/dL.
explanation: LDL stands for Low-Density Lipoprotein, often called 'bad cholesterol' because high levels contribute to atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease. HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) is 'good cholesterol' that helps remove LDL from arteries. Optimal LDL is below 100 mg/dL. Lipid panel testing is coded under CPT 80061.

scenario: A surgeon documents a plantar fasciotomy for plantar fasciitis.
explanation: Plantar refers to the sole (bottom) of the foot. Plantar fasciitis is inflammation of the plantar fascia on the bottom of the foot. Dorsal refers to the top of the foot. Palmar (volar) refers to the palm of the hand. Dorsal refers to the back of the hand. These directional terms are specific to the extremities and important for accurate anatomical coding.

scenario: A radiologist describes bilateral lesions on a chest CT scan.
explanation: Bilateral means on both sides: 'bi-' (two) + 'lateral' (side). Bilateral pulmonary nodules means nodules in both lungs. In CPT coding, bilateral procedures may use modifier -50 or be coded with separate codes for each side using -RT (right) and -LT (left) modifiers. Unilateral means one side. Contralateral means opposite side.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with tinnitus. The ENT specialist evaluates the patient's hearing.

answers.text: Ringing or buzzing in the ears

explanation: Tinnitus is the perception of ringing, buzzing, hissing, or other sounds in the ears without an external source. It can be subjective (heard only by the patient) or objective (can be heard by the examiner). Common causes include noise exposure, age-related hearing loss, and ear infections. Hearing loss is called 'hearing impairment' or 'deafness.' Vertigo is dizziness.

scenario: A patient is diagnosed with ascites. The gastroenterologist performs a paracentesis.

answers.text: Fluid accumulation in the peritoneal (abdominal) cavity

explanation: Ascites is the accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal (abdominal) cavity. Common causes include liver cirrhosis, heart failure, and cancer. Pleural effusion is fluid in the pleural space (around the lungs). Pericardial effusion is fluid around the heart. Hydrocephalus is excess fluid in the brain ventricles. Paracentesis is the procedure to drain ascitic fluid.

scenario: A surgeon performs a fulguration of bladder tumors during cystoscopy.

answers.text: Destruction of tissue using electric current

explanation: Fulguration is the destruction of tissue using high-frequency electric current (electrocautery/electrosurgery). It is commonly used to destroy small bladder tumors during cystoscopy. Cryotherapy (cryosurgery) uses freezing. Laser ablation uses focused light energy. Excision uses a scalpel or surgical instrument. The method of tissue destruction affects CPT code selection.

scenario: A surgeon performs a curettage of a bone cyst. The operative note describes scraping the cyst cavity.

answers.text: Scraping tissue from a surface using a curette

explanation: Curettage means scraping tissue from a surface using a spoon-shaped instrument called a curette. It is used for bone cysts, uterine tissue sampling (D&C - dilation and curettage), and skin lesion removal. Curettage may be combined with electrodesiccation for skin cancer treatment. The term comes from the French 'curette' (scraper).

scenario: A pathology report describes an infarction of the myocardium. The cardiologist diagnoses acute myocardial infarction.

answers.text: Tissue death due to lack of blood supply

explanation: Infarction means tissue death (necrosis) due to lack of blood supply (ischemia). Myocardial infarction (heart attack) is death of heart muscle due to blocked coronary arteries.
